channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2023090248
item.description:
Report E-2023090248

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-14T03:11:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-06
  • City: Easley
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR EXPRESS AMERICA, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 06, 2023, at 1135 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Easley, South Carolina regarding the release of approximately (1) gallon of ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE C, LIQUID, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED (UN3113, 5.2) from (1) 5-gallon Jerrican. Contractors were dispatched to the site to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors were informed by facility personnel that the release was due to a load shift during transit and contained to the trailer floor. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. Facility personnel cleaned and containerized the release prior to contractorsâ€™ arrival and will be responsible for managing the waste.

item.title: Report E-2023090232
item.description:
Report E-2023090232

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-14T03:11:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-06
  • City: BATTLE CREEK
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 6, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote containing UN1805 was damaged due to falling off the lift gate and released approximately eighty (80) gallons of product to the soil. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from SET Environmental (SET) to remediate the impacted site. SET personnel deployed poly sheeting around the impacted areas and patched the one (1) damaged tote. The crew returned the next day to perform a tote transfer. SET personnel conducted a gravity transfer of the remaining material from the damaged tote into one (1) new 330-gallon tote provided by on-site management. Crews deployed a neutralizing agent to the impacted area. Once neutralized, SET personnel utilized a back hoe to remove the impacted soil. The excavated area was backfilled with clean soil, graded to match pre-existing topography, and covered with erosion matting to promote vegetative growth. All impacted soil was collected and containerized into one (1) roll off and staged on-site pending waste profiling for disposal purposes. One (1) background and one (1) confirmation sample were obtained from the site, placed into laboratory approved containers, and transported under chain of custody protocol to the laboratory.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: While traveling down the non-conveyable belt the package somehow ended up on its side. One bottle with the loose cap leaked but the spillage was absorbed by the box and nothing was released. The bottle that leaked was the TISAB I, which does not appear to be a hazmat. The Sulfuric Acid that is a hazmat does not appear to have leaked. DescribePack: The bottle of TISAB I had a slightly loose cap so it did not have a complete seal. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The box absorbed the release. The box was immediately put into a hazmat bin in order to separate it from all other packages.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On August 25, 2023, sixteen (16) one-gallon pails of UN1263 primer were crushed during transit and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer floor and pavement underneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services, Inc. (HES) to remediate the impacted site. The crew collected the damaged pails and placed them in one (1) 30-gallon drum for disposal. Personnel then deployed granular absorbents and worked them in using hand tools. All impacted material was containerized in two (2) 55-gallon drums for disposal.

The release was contained to the trailer floor and asphalt beneath the trailer. Terminal personnel felt comfortable cleaning up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. item.title: Report E-2023090124
item.description:
Report E-2023090124

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-13
  • City: Eureka
  • State: NV
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HUNT & SONS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver was distracted trying to pick up spilled soda off of the floor and took his eyes off of the road when his Semi left the right side of the road. When he looked back up he realized that all wheels were off of the road and tried to correct. When his pup was coming back on the highway it rolled over on the drivers side of the pup. Driver continued to try to get control of the rig and dragged the pup for approximately 1/4 mile, spilling fuel the whole way, until the equipment came to a stop on the westbound lane. Upon inspection of the crash site the driver observed several spot fires so he grabbed his 20# extinguisher and attempted to put them out, Shortly after stopping he observed that the tank was on fire so he unhooked his main from the pup and moved the truck down the road. The pup became engulfed in flames and was a total loss as well as the 3500 gal of Diesel fuel. Since that time Hunt and Sons has put on safety meetings at all locations for "Distracted Driving" and are in the process of turning on the in-cab cameras to help coach individuals who become distracted while driving.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-13T18:13:54+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-14
  • City: EAST WENATCHEE
  • State: WA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Pkg unloaded from trailer, package handler noticed wet staining of outer pack. Sent to QA, upon retail inspection found one box with 4 one gallon jugs of Pro-Brown coil cleaner, with one leaking contents. SDS sheet placed with inner package by shipper, sheet states LTD QTY less than 1L. No limited quantity label on outer pack, greater than 1L in package. Inner package has diamond label UN3266. Leaking contents also soaked into other inner package. DescribePack: 4 one gallon jugs in fiberboard box, one gallon jug leaking from cap. Cap is not loose and will not tighten down to stop leaking. Closure failure on the jug cap, inner seal or contact. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: package trapped and taken to QA where contents inspected and stood up right so jug stopped leaking. Leaking liquid only soaked into outer pack, did not damage other packages or surroundings.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NKX experienced a UN3105 Norox MCP-75 Red release from a 5-gallon jerrican. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 5-gallons of product released impacting an 8â€™ x 10â€™ area of the trailer floor and a 10â€™ x 10â€™ area of the concrete lot below due to the pail being crushed as a result of stacking. Oil dri was deployed onto the impacted areas and worked into to clean and remove all free-standing liquid. The damaged empty jug, absorbents, PPE, and spill pads were then collected into a 55-gallon vented poly drum. An impacted pallet was also cut up and placed into a separate 55-gallon vented poly drum. Both drums were submerged with water per XPOâ€™s waste vendor requirements. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

All waste generated was containerized in (1) roll-off by contractors which was staged onsite in preparation for proper disposal.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-09
  • City: HUNKER
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: During transpiration back to the station, the bucket tipped over and rolled inside the truck, striking a bolt causing the perfect circle puncture. With some spillage in truck (Unknow cleanup). Upon arriving to work to check our VSA cart which drivers leave packages that are marked for QA service, I noticed a hazmat bucket lying on it side. Further investigating I saw a small hole at the bottom of the plastic pail. I placed a red hazmat bin on top on the bucket to prevent other packages being placed around it. Procced to acquire a yellow barrel, hazmat bags, gloves, inner stuffing and, absorb pads. Placed gloves on hands and placed absorb pads around leakage on the VSA cart, lifted plastic drum into red hazmat bin for processing, processed and placed into yellow drum with inner fillings and into hazmat cage. DescribePack: Small screw sized hold 1/2 inch from bottom of drum. inward puncture DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: drum was placed on side, using absorb pad and tape to prevent excess spillage during transportation.

item.title: Report X-2023080836
item.description:
Report X-2023080836

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-11T03:12:58+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-09
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: THE PACKAGE WAS FOUND LEAKING ON OUR LOADING DOCK. IT WAS IN AN UNMARKED BOX THAT HAD BEEN REPACKED BY ANOTHER STATION WHO FAILED TO ADD ANY UP ARROWS OR DIAMOND LABELS ONTO THE PACKAGE. THEY DID TAPE THE OP-900 TO THE PACKAGE. THE ADMIN PLACED THE PACKAGE INTO A LINED TOTE AND BROUGH IT TO THE HAZ CAGE FOR INSPECTION. THEY ALSO FAILED TO RELABEL THE PACKAGE THEY JUST REPACKED IT INTO AN UNMARKED BOX AND TRIED TO SEND IT FORWARD. DescribePack: THE PACKAGE WAS WAY TO BIG FOR JUST THE THREE ITEMS THAT WERE LOOSE INSIDE OF IT. NORMALLY THESE PACKAGES CONTAIN FOUR BOTTLES NOT JUST THREE. WHICH LEADS ME TO BELIEVE SINCE IT WAS REPACKED IF THE MISSING BOTTLE MAY OF BEEN DAMAGED. ONE OF THE ITEMS INSIDE THE PACKAGE DID OPEN FROM THE LID CAUSING IT TO SPILL OUT. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE DAMAGED ITEM WAS PLACED INSIDE A LINED DRUM FOR PROCESSING. THE LAST TWO UNDAMGED ITEMS HAVE BEEN PROPERLY REPACKED SO THEY MAY BE RTS.

  • Description: On Flight 382, the passenger came into the aft galley wanting to dispose of what looked like tissue in her hand. The Flight Attendant opened the lid of the trash cart so she could throw it in. The Flight Attendant caught the sight of a light purple color. She asked the passenger about it and she mentioned it was a Vape. The Flight Attendant said,"A Vape?" and she said yes. Flight Attendant called the Captain and explained what had happened. She then tells me it was warm. Flight Attendant tells the passenger"We need to take it out of the trash cart now", which we did. Flight Attendant calls the Capt back and told him the Vape was warm and if he wants me to put it in a bucket of ice water. He instructs me to place it in the fire containment bag. Flight Attendant followed the procedures for this and placed it in a cart. The passenger and Flight Attendant walked out of the aircraft together and the Flight Attendant handed the bag to the Agent. The Flight Attendant was very grateful the passenger did not throw the item in the Iavatory trash container. Note: Overheating Vape was a Iceberry Lemon Flum Float vape.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Description: On July 2, 2023 at approximately 7:15 PM, a Plains transport driver with a load of crude oil was traveling southbound on State Highway 42 in Gregg County, TX. At the intersection of Hwy 42 and Texaco Rd, a 2012 Nissan traveling east on Texaco Rd failed to stop at a stop sign and collided with Plains transport, causing the tank trailer to separate from the tractor and roll over into the ditch. Upon separation, the landing gear broke off and punctured a 3x3 inch hole in the trailer, at the 7 o'clock position if upright, but upon roll over, puncture was located at the 10 o'clock position. As a result of the collision, 70 gallons of diesel from the transport fuel tank and approximately 2 gallons of hydraulic fluid, from the trailer hydraulic pump and lines, were released to the roadway and roadside ditch. The Plains vehicle and the other vehicle were non drivable and had to be towed from the scene. An absorbent was applied to the roadway to encapsulate the diesel and hydraulic fluid, then swept and contained in 55 gallon drums. The impacted roadside ditch has been excavated to remove impacted soil and manifested for disposal, in accordance with TCEQ clean-up criteria. . . The Plains employee was injured and treated at a medical facility. Occupant of other vehicle perished at the scene.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 2
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 7-11-23: At approx 2100 hrs, in Morgantown WV our truck / trailer carrying UN,2312, Phenol, Molten, 6.1, II was flagged down. A mist from the top of the tanker trailer had landed on a car following our TT; Due to the HM product, EMS was activated. Fire, Police and HM responded. There was an light odor of the product in the air. A check of a valve at the top of the tanker revealed that hit was not fully closed. The driver had performed a pre trip inspection and the valve was closed at that time. No product was exiting the tank at this time. The product, which is not under pressure, would only be able to exit that valve while ascending or descending inclines. On flat ground the productÂ· would not be able to be released. The valve was secured by HM Responders. The tanker was allowed to complete the remainder of the trip ( Approx 1/2 mile) to be unloaded. Two passerbys claimed to be affected by the product. They were transported to a local hospital for observations, then released. C Three Logistics has contracted with a HM response cleanup operation to properly decontaminate the exterior of the affected motor vehicle.

item.title: Report X-2023080915
item.description:
Report X-2023080915

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-11T03:12:58+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-07-19
  • City: JONESBORO
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The hazmat pkg was on a closure cart in the middle area by our chutes where the closures and misloads go. I had checked on the package earlier to see where it needed to go, and did not see any leaking around the package. Someone had grabbed the cart that the package was on, and put it on the rollers attached to the chute, and about 30 minutes later, I heard the manager call out that there was a leaking Hazmat. I ran over to the area, and the manager, a PH, and another QA were picking up the leaking, corrosive Hazmat with their bare hands, putting it into a tote, and making the package leak everywhere. I immediately told them to set the package down and to clear the area. I let them know that it was a corrosive liquid and that it could burn them. They had already set it on the tugger, and it was leaking all over the back of the tugger as well. They set it down, and I grabbed it, and put it on my QA cart. When I set it on the cart, the liquid splashed up on my arms and on my left leg (as I was wearing shorts), and it started burning my skin. I told them to immediately clear the area, go rinse their hands, and I took my cart to the QA area, and hurried to the Hazmat shower to start rinsing my arms and leg off. After I had rinsed off for about 8 to 10 mins, I then went back and got the tugger that had been leaked on, and took it to the QA area to put it out of order. I then took my QA cart to the Hazmat cage and put the damaged portion of the package into a lined salvage drum. DescribePack: Package failed due to a loose cap on one of the bottles of Warewashing Detergents. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: I went to the spill area, and put the chemical neutralizer onto the spilled liquid and then put the shredded absorbing material onto it as well. I put caution tape over the area, and the next morning, I pH tested several spots, as well as the spots on the tugger, and then put down more neutralizer as needed. I then waited until about 11:00a that morning to sweep up the neutralizer and absorbing material into a hazardous material bag, and place it into the salvage drum with the other damaged portion of the damaged package.
